system.common:
You should always be wary of a lone person wandering through the woods. That’s not to say every person wandering the woods alone is a threat but it’s a safe habit to adopt. Besides the odd bandit, you may encounter a scout surveying out the area for one reason or another. They’re usually simply checking the perimeter of a town or ensuring a monster isn’t wandering too near to their village but in some cases you’ll come face to face with a military scout. It’s here you’ll have to be cautious. Scouts employed by a kingdom’s army can’t afford to be spotted. They might try to do you in to make sure their position isn’t given away to potential enemies.
—Siriol de Arian
system.academicKnowledge:
Scouts are employed by kingdoms, cities, and villages all over the Continent. Being well versed in wilderness survival and bushcraft, they’re often sent to hostile or uncharted territories to see what information they can gather. Smaller villages often employ scouts to find new sources of resources like medicinal herbs and lands suitable for mining. In most cases they pose little threat to other travelers and carry only weapons to protect themselves from the dangers of the wilderness. In the past, before the creation of the witchers, scouts were often employed to keep watch on powerful monsters making their homes near villages but this practice is almost unheard of now.

Military scouts are a different matter. These scouts are trained in combat and most often sent on spying mission. Their job is to sneak into enemy territory and glean as much information as possible without getting caught. They’re taught to assess dangers, count enemy troops, locate enemy commanders, and take detailed notes on the enemies resources and movements. Of course, this task is extremely dangerous and a scout who’s unfortunate enough to be captured can expect to be beaten, tortured, and likely killed. Still, a scout behind enemy lines is unlikely to kill someone unless they have to. It’s easier to intimidate a civilian into staying quiet or pay them a bribe to keep them from going to the local authorities than to kill them and risk someone finding the body or noticing the oddity of a missing person.

system.description: When a Scout rolls a Wilderness Survival check to track a target, they roll with a +5 bonus.

A Scout carries 10 Broadhead Arrows for leaving bleeding wounds on their targets. When the scout makes an attack with their Longbow using one of these arrows and deals damage, the target has a 100% chance of suffering the Bleeding Condition.

"Always carry some rope. I've been trapped in holes, needed to climb cliffs. All sorts of times rope'd be useful."
-Rodolf Kazmer

"I've slept on the ground a lot. A bedroll's a nice thing to have. Nice comfy pad to sleep on with a blanket to cover ya."
-Rodolf Kazmer

"A chunk of flint and a steel loop. Strike 'em together and you'll create a shower of sparks that'll light small fires."
-Rodolf Kazmer

"Better to have a lantern but a torch'll do you pretty well in a pinch. Spreads light pretty well and i guess if ya gotta you can swing it like a club."
-Rodolf Kazmer

Raises light levels by 1 for 5m all around.

Redaninan Crown:
-3 Kaedweni Ducats
-1 Temerian Oren
-1/2 Hengfor Lintar
-1/3 Nilfgaardian Floren
-1/4 Koviri Bizant
Daggers come in all kinds of shapes and sizes but theyâ€™re always small enough to hide. Everyone carries one, from knights to peasants.
Over time Iâ€™ve gotten fond of the hand axe. Heh, used to use â€˜em for timber but theyâ€™re damn tough, and a weapon designed to chop wood will go through bone just as well.

The long bowâ€™s the predecessor to the crossbow. Personally, think theyâ€™re large and unwieldy. But hey, easy to say that when youâ€™re shorter than the bow. Elves swear by the long bow and in their hands itâ€™s probably the deadliest ranged weapon short of a damn ballista. Humans generally moved to the crossbow, but down in Nilfgaard theyâ€™ve got plenty of archers, all deadly and perfectly willinâ€™ to prove it.

Heh, if ya got a weapon that throws a projectile, ya need projectiles. Standard ammunition is basically your typical bolt or arrow. Bolts are usually smaller than arrows, but they both have a sharp metal head and feather fletching.

Broadheads are some of the best alternate projectiles to have on hand. Theyâ€™re much like normal bolts or arrows but instead of having a simple metal head they have a wide, flat, bladed head. Heh, come in all shapes and sizes, leaves, diamonds, v shapes, and such but they all cut deeper than regular arrows, leavinâ€™ bleedinâ€™ wounds.

Hoods can be armored pretty easily. Addinâ€™ leather, chain, and such like that. These hoods are woven tighter than any other to make it harder for weapons to penetrate â€˜em. Heh, simple and effective.

The Aedirnians probably had it the worst when Nilfgaard attacked. Lost their kingâ€”not even sure whether they had a new king before a wave of black and gold hit â€˜em. The Aedirnian gambesonâ€™s evidence of that. Just a gambeson with scraps of leather and hardened hide stitched on here and there.
Heh, basically just a gambeson for your legs. Paddinâ€™ll turn a small blade but I wouldnâ€™t rely on it too much. You should see the cod-pieces though: never laughed so hard in my life.
